boardgame.name: Downstream
boardgame.description:
Downstream is a puzzly 2 player card laying game where players create a river and attempt to enrich their own shoreline.

In the game, players add cards to a growing river ecosystem; either extending the flow of water or tucked to extend existing banks.

Cards extending the flow add scoring features to either shore while tucking cards means a missed opportunity to affect the flow of water.

Players compete to achieve a varying set of objectives in each game, the resulting rivers having their own personality.

—description from the designer

From the introduction:

618 is a game of conspiracy, in which you investigate the true purpose of a mysterious institution.

It is set in the near future: but a "retro-future", a bleak near-future, as seen from the 1960s or 1970s.

It is a world of grey concrete buildings and automated filing cabinets; of room-sized computers and terminals glowing green; of men in thin ties and women in make-up. For inspiration, think of the TV series The Prisoner or Terry Gilliam's film Brazil.

boardgame.name: Acts of Creation
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

In the beginning, the world was created, and it was an Abomination.

In the time before the world, the Four Eidolon, the Lords of the Elements, held court in the formlessness of the Cosmos on their Everchanging Thrones. Fire was as ice, stone was as water. Each Eidolon was possessed of a Nemesis, the shade of their glory, the millstone of doubt hung 'round the neck of the omnipotent Lords.

How did it come, then, that Leviathan: Cold Lord, Blood Lord, formed a dark pact with his Nemesis? How did it come that Leviathan, embraced and corrupted and consumed, became Creator, pulling a World screaming from the Timeless Ocean into bright being?

With his Creation, Leviathan corrupted the whole of Eternity, and set himself apart from the Eidolon. Its awful brilliance, however, gave over a glimmer of the Truth – that the Nemeses were one and the same - fingers on the Hand of Downfall, a Lord of Ruin set among the Eidolon to subvert the Cosmos to his own design – to shackle, to imprison, to corrupt and infuse the Cosmos with none but his own Will.

And so begins the First Age of World, the Eidolon set against Nemesis and beset from within by the very thing they long to defy. Come the Fifth Age, the Reckoning Age, all will be decided, for good or ill – and the Terrible World will perish or become the seed for a Cosmos of Glittering Tyranny.

boardgame.name: Ariel
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

Ariel's feet had never touched the ground. As far as she was concerned, the distant sea was just a reflection of the sky. The islands came and went like clouds, their coastlines no more substantial than water stains on a map.

She turned the screws and the gas jets fired, burning holes in the clouds behind her. At this height nothing in the air could catch her. Her ship was like some exotic flying fish that refused to return to the ocean, its copper scales all green with rust and encrusted here and there with turquoise. One day it would spring a leak and sink to the bottom of the deep blue sky, and she would die, just like everyone else who had ever run aground, but not today. The world was far too big and slow. Just let it try to catch her.

boardgame.name: Loopy Llamas
boardgame.description: Players take turns moving around the swimming pool playing board collecting one of each of the coloured rings to stack on their 3D llama. Then race to be the first to get your llama to dive into the swimming pool to win the fame!

boardgame.name: An Artist First
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

"In every first novel the hero is the author as Christ or Faust." Oscar Wilde said that. In hindsight, it makes quite a bit of sense. Every artist, no matter the medium, has one goal: immortality. As one starts down this path, there is nothing that weighs heavier on her head than whether she will be the messiah of her craft or face condemnation as a petty fool who let her talents wither.

boardgame.name: Mullensburg Rising
boardgame.description:
This is the second part of the Concordance of Freedom adventure path.

A few days have passed since the party took care of the Castilian who was under the sway of Chaos and stopped the abductions that were plaguing the town of Mullensburg. The group’s rest is short lived though as the Barron sets out to find those responsible for the death of his right-hand man. This launches the players into the Adventure path proper which is a massive endeavor that will send them across Lapsburg and plunge them into its fractured politics and brewing civil war. Mullensburg Rising should take 4-5 characters to the end of their first, or early into their second, profession. Content Warning for Graphic disturbing violence and implied sexual assault and rape. Recommended for Mature audiences.

boardgame.name: Factions of Fuchsstadt
boardgame.description:
Factions of Fuchsstadt is the third part of the Concordance of Freedom Adventure Path. In this section the players have survived the Skrzzak filled sewers and arrived inside the broken and war-torn city of Fuchsstadt. Once here they will get sucked into the Concordance’s attempts to retake the city, and perhaps also help The High Justice hunt down collaborators and bring them to swift “justice”. This is an adventure for Characters who are in the early section of the
intermediate tier.

The trek through the sewers was hell, and possibly breaking for some characters. But it’s not over, if you thought the camps and sewers were a nightmare, then nothing can prepare you for what awaits in Fuchsstadt. Inside the city are three factions. The Concordance rebels and Barronburg locked in mortal combat, and the Lapsburg refugees and civilians caught in the middle. Like wildfire rumor spreads through the city that an attack is coming led by forces from Quinlenwald - a Lapsburg loyal city far to the east. The citizenry will latch onto anything at this point to stop the violence. The once prosperous city has been turned into a horrific abattoir where the worst of humanity is on display.

CW: Graphic Violence, Refugee Crisis, Terrorism, Ethno-Nationalist Violence

boardgame.name: Courts of Quinlenwald
boardgame.description:
Courts of Quinlenwald is the fourth part of the Concordance of Freedom adventure path. It is designed for a party halfway through the intermediate tier. The adventure picks up as the party has been captured by forces from Quinlenwald and carted away from the sacked city of Fuchsstadt.

Charged with high crimes the players are being taken across the country to stand trial in the notoriously litigious city of Quinlenwald. But there is something going on under the surface of the city, can the party expose the conspiracy in time to save their lives? By the end of the adventure, the party should be entering the Advanced tier.

boardgame.name: Ashes of Mullensburg
boardgame.description:
Ashes of Mullensburg is the fifth and final part of The Concordance of Freedom adventure path. The party has been sent away from Quinlenwald under the sentence of Death by Heroism and under the care of the Witch Hunter Marie. They are setting out toward the town of Beltagrad where forces are
gathering to deal with the corruption that has overtaken The Spike. They are doing this in the hopes of preventing an Exterminatus of Lapsburg.

This is an adventure for Characters who are just starting their expert tier profession. This product contains, strong violence and Language, along with drug abuse, ethno-nationalist violence, andgeneral hopeless feelings. Intended for Mature audiences. You will need a copy of ZWEIHÄNDER:
Revised Core Rulebook, MAIN GAUCHE, and the GRIM WARDEN’S Supplement to run this adventure. The Grim Wardens can be found on the Grim and Perilous Library and is included with
the Concordance of Freedom Bundle.

boardgame.name: Kicikol!
boardgame.description:
A player draws a Black card and reads it aloud. Then, all players choose a Red card from their hand that would fill the |...| of the Black card. To make their Red card more interesting, all players choose 1 sticker and stick it on the Red card. As soon as everyone is ready, the creations are revealed in turn. As soon as everyone is ready, all players point to their favorite Red card. The player with the most votes wins the card.

Create funny or surprising combinations to fill in the |...| of the Black card. With the stickers your game will become unique and full of epic memories! Finally a communication game for the whole family.

boardgame.name: Barbie: Il Giro del Mondo
boardgame.description:
In this game you are Barbie. A well-known travel company offers you the opportunity to go around the world to collect documentation on the cities visited. A prize is awarded to you for each documentation. You will win if you reach $ 100,000 first, as long as you have at least one ticket for each of the 6 continents.

The players draw 10 letters from a bag with which they must be able to compose the name of a city they want to reach. If they succeed, they move their marker to the city and are rewarded with $ (depending on the city), otherwise they draw another letter and pass the turn to the next player.

boardgame.name: The British Way: Counterinsurgency at the End of Empire
boardgame.description:
The British Way: Counterinsurgency at the End of Empire is the first of several COIN multipacks, containing four separate games exploring a series of thematically related insurgencies. Between 1945 and 1960, the British fought four major “emergencies”, as they referred to their counterinsurgency campaigns, each trying to manage their retreat from empire. The four games in this pack focus on exploring British counterinsurgent responses to a variety of different opponents, including communist insurgents in Malaya, militant nationalists in Kenya, and smaller and more clandestine terrorist organizations in Palestine and Cyprus. The games adjust the core COIN mechanics to provide a compelling new way of handling two-player conflicts, while also streamlining several mechanics to quicken gameplay. The British Way offers an approachable introduction to the COIN series for new players, while presenting experienced players with four mechanically distinct games to explore and compare.

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Seesaw
boardgame.description:
Seesaw is a Draughts-inspired elimination game, played on a hexhex board of size 4 or 5. Each player needs, in their own color, a large number of stackable tokens and tiles.

Rules

Overview:
In Seesaw the players command opposing armies of soldiers that can promote. Your army starts out as a single soldier in the bottom corner. This soldier stands on a tile of your color. This tile is your initial promotion area, and it will evolve as you deploy more soldiers. Every time a soldier promotes it grows - first into a 2-stack, then a 3-stack, and so on.

The central idea of Seesaw is the 2-fold significance of stack-size:
(i) Odd-sized stacks move forwards and even-sized stacks move backwards, and
(ii) on any given turn, a stack can take as many steps as it likes from 1 up to its size.

This results in soldiers seesawing up and down the board as their strength increases to the point where the game is forced to conclude in one side completely eliminating the other.

How to play:
On your turn, you must either move a stack, or place a new stack.

1. Placing a new stack:
A newly placed stack will always be of size 1. You may only place a stack on an empty cell next to a cell with a tile of your color. These cells are promotion cells, and each time you place a new stack you first place a tile of your color on that cell. A cell with a tile on it is not considered empty, but tiles never count toward stacks-size.

2. Moving a stack:
You only ever move one stack per turn, but that stack may be able to move several steps or capture several enemy stacks, depending on its size.
The number of steps a stack may take is the number of pieces in it, i.e. its size. A stack may never step onto a cell containing a stack of its color.

2.1 Noncapturing moves: On turns where you do not have to capture an enemy (see below) all the steps a stack takes is either constrained to the 3 upward directions ("forwards") or to the 3 downward directions ("backwards"), depending on the parity of the size of the stack. Up and down have their standard meanings for games where players sit on opposite sides of a board, like in Draughts and Chess.

2.2 Capturing moves: If one or more of your stacks can reach an enemy by lifting the restraint on direction, you must capture such a reachable enemy by replacement. If that stack did not spend all its steps reaching the captured enemy, you can, before you end your turn, spend the left-over steps by making a noncapturing move. However, if yet an enemy is in range immediately after you have captured (counting only the steps left over), you must capture again.

3. Promoting: Your odd-sized stacks promote when they end up on a promotion cell belonging to your opponent at the end of your turn. Your even-sized stacks promote when they end up on a promotion cell belonging to you at the end of your turn. When a stack promotes, you add 1 piece to it.

The object of Seesaw is to capture all your opponent's soldiers. More precisely: If, at the end of your turn, your opponent has no stacks on the board, you have won the game.

boardgame.name: Revolution Timeline: México
boardgame.description: Goal of the game: to be the only person with no cards remaining in front of you. If the players believes that their card dates from BEFORE the initial card, they place their card to the LEFT of the initial card, if they believes that their card dates from AFTER the initial card, they place their card to the RIGHT of the initial card.

boardgame.name: Volfyirion Guilds: Omen Expansion
boardgame.description:
Bring to the table the inscrutable force of fate through a set collection mechanic. Make the Omen come true by collecting signs, sacrificing immediate gains to unravel treacherous powers.

The Omen is a new type of card which comes along with its own several abilities. An Omen card allows you to beat your opponents by building a long term alternative strategy that could be a game changer, if deployed in the right moment. This kind of strategy is not costless, but it surely leads to huge rewards.

The new Omen cards provide powerful effects that need specific set collections to trigger. The cards collected in this way are called Signs and can be added or removed during the game, offering new opportunities for direct interaction between players.

Volfyirion Guilds - Omen Expansion is not a standalone game.
It can be played either with Volfyirion, or Volfyirion Guilds in 1vs1 mode.

The Omen Expansion can be combined with Volfyirion, Volfyirion Guilds, or any other expansion, for an even more challenging experience. In any case we do not recommend combining more than two expansions at the same time.

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Volfyirion Guilds: Ploy Expansion
boardgame.description:
Accomplish your Guild's hidden agenda through low blows and tricky interruptions during the opponent's turn that will increase the complexity and tension of the game.

The Ploy is a new type of card which comes along with its own several abilities.
A Ploy Card, with its asymmetric and secret new strategy, may allow you to beat your opponent, overwriting the rules of the game in specific conditions.

The new Ploy cards provide alternative ways to interact with the opponent, even during their turn, to sabotage their strategies when needed. A Ploy card must remain face down until they are played, but Ploys can also be drawn, forcefully revealed, swapped, or removed by the effect of other abilities during the game.

Volfyirion Guilds Ploy Expansion is not a standalone game.
It can be played either with Volfyirion, or Volfyirion Guilds in 1vs1 mode.
The Ploy Expansion can be combined with Volfyirion, Volfyirion Guilds, or any other expansion, for an even more challenging experience. In any case we do not recommend combining more than two expansions at the same time.

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Fire & Stone
Fuego y Piedra
刀耕與火種
boardgame.description:
In Fire & Stone, players lead their tribe through the Stone Age. They scout new lands, harvest nuts and mushrooms, and finally build villages. The aim of the game is to have the most successful tribe by exploring new lands, building huts, and gathering resources. With the invention of new tools and techniques like ship building or pottery, the expansion of your tribe can even be accelerated.

Each space the scouts can enter contains upside-down discover tokens. When a scout moves on one of those tokens for the first time, the token is revealed and triggers an effect. From now on these tokens can be used as a player action with a different effect. By the end of the game, the player who made the most victory points with villages and accomplishing tasks wins.

boardgame.name: Mity
boardgame.description:
Mity is a simple territory game of pure placement. It is played on the cells of a hexhex board.

Rules

Players place one token of their color each turn and the first player unable to do so has lost. You may place on any empty cell unless your opponent has a token closer to that cell than you have along at least 2 of the 3 lines (axes) the cell is on.

The game uses the pie rule: One player chooses the first move and the other player chooses whose move it is.

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: Garner
boardgame.description:
Garner is a combinatorial card game for two players where you seek to collect a majority of cards in a majority of suits. It is played with a deck of cards containing 5 suits of 15 numbers each.

Setup:
Shuffle the deck and fan out 25 stacks of 3 cards each in a regular layout of 5 rows and 5 columns. All cards should be visible, and it should be clear which cards are on which layer of the layout. (The 25 top cards in the initial position are on the top layer, and underneath that there are two more layers of 25 cards each.)

Definitions:
Every card belongs in a number group together with all and only those cards which are connected to it by a sequence of orthogonal steps between cards with equal numbers. The members of a group all lie on the same layer.
A suit group is defined the same way, except "number" is replaced with "suit".

Play:
On your turn, you first distribute a number group, then you collect a suit group.

Distribute: Pick up a number group from the current top layer and distribute them anew on the layout. You may not place two of these cards in the same stack, and you may not place them underneath any cards. Other than that, you are free to choose any of the 25 sites in the layout. There is no limit on how many cards there can be at each site.

Collect: Pick up any suit group from the current top layer and store those cards in a personal scoring pile on your side of the board.

Ending the game:
When all cards are collected, the winner is the player whose scoring pile contains the majority of the cards in the majority of the suits.

Slight variations:

Add the requirement that all cards (or at least one card) in the chosen number group are in a new position after distributing.
When distributing, cards must be moved in a straight (diagonal or orthogonal) line.


Decks you can play Garner with:
Rage
Stick 'Em
5°Dimension Playing Card Game
Sluff Off!
Tricky Bid
David & Goliath

Ways of playing with more traditional decks:

(A)

9 cards in 3 suits from a standard French deck.
Layout: 9 stacks of 3 cards each in a 3x3 grid.


(B)

12 cards in 3 suits from a standard French deck.
Layout: 9 stacks of 4 cards each in a 3x3 grid.
Extra rule: You may never have exactly 6 cards in a suit in your scoring pile. If collecting a suit group would bring the number of cards you have in that suit to 6, you must leave behind a card in the layout, even if it means collecting 0 cards.


(C)

13 cards in 3 suits and 9 cards in 1 suit from a standard French deck.
Layout: 16 stacks of 3 cards each in a 4x4 grid.
Extra rule: The suit with 9 cards is worth half a suit.


(D)

9 cards in 4 suits from a standard French deck and 9 cards in a suit form a different deck, like a German deck or Tarot deck.
Layout: 15 stacks of 3 cards each in a 3x5 grid.


(E)

12 cards in 4 suits from a standard French deck and 12 cards in a suit form a different deck, like a German deck or Tarot deck.
Layout: 20 stacks of 3 cards each in a 4x5 grid.
Extra rule: You may never have exactly 6 cards in a suit in your scoring pile. If collecting a suit group would bring the number of cards you have in that suit to 6, you must leave behind a card in the layout, even if it means collecting 0 cards.


—description from the designer

boardgame.name: Noose
boardgame.description:
Noose is played on a hexhex board with stones of two colors, one color belonging to each player. The winner of the game is the player to first make a loop consisting entirely of stones of their color.

Rules:
On your turn, you must either (i) place a stone of your color on an empty hex, or (ii) flip an eligible arc of enemy stones. You may not do both.

Definitions:
To flip an enemy stone is to replace it with a stone of your own, from your (preferably endless) supply.

An arc is a possibly bent line of stones with no acute angles and no turns going in opposite directions (no S-like swingyness). (Se below for a more precise definition of an arc.)

You are said to flank an arc of enemy pieces if two of your pieces are the endpoints of an arc otherwise completely made up of said enemy pieces.

You may flip an arc of enemy pieces if you are the only one flanking it.

A loop is a group of stones causing one or more cells not contained in that group to be severed from the edges of the board in this sense: There is no chain of adjacent cells going from any of those severed cells to any edge cell that does not contain at least one stone from the loop group. (It's a curve of stones biting itself in the ass, around at least one enemy stone or at least one empty cell.)

More precise definition of an arc:
A chain of adjacent pieces make up an arc if it is possible to order them from first to last in a sequence where a walk from the first to the last member of the chain, visiting all members in order, will (i) at no point require a turn of more than 60 degrees, and (ii) either require no clockwise turns or no counter-clockwise turns.

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: Unknot
boardgame.description:
Unknot is played on a hexhex board oriented so that there is a horizontal line of adjacent cells between one pair of two opposing corner cells.

Both players share a pool of stones of a single color and take turns placing then onto empty cells.

Placement restrictions.

The center cell is unplayable throughout the game.
Player 1 may not place immediately northwest of a stone.
Player 2 may not place immediately northeast of a stone.


The game is over as soon as one player completes a loop of pieces around at least one empty cell. This player is then the winner. The game cannot end in a draw, so can also be played with the opposite goal: The player who completes a loop loses.

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: Remigio, lungo viaggio alla ricerca della mamma
boardgame.description:
The players play the role of Remigio, a child in search of his mother. They will have to reach various places on the map where they can discover clues that will lead them to discover the identity of their mother, hidden at the beginning of the game in a secret place. In the various places visited they will be able to acquire objects that will allow them to move faster, to be the first to discover the identity of their mother and thus win the game.
The game is evidently inspired by the cartoon television series Remi, broadcast in Italy for the first time in 1979

boardgame.name: The Complete Illustrated Book of Enchantment
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

The Complete Illustrated Book of ENCHANTMENT is the 7th installment to my fan art based project of illustrating ALL 8 schools of magic compatible with 5e. This tome is taken from the life's work of the Enchantress, San Briel.

Each spelbook contains a little journal in the beginning that interlocks throughout the eight grimoires. There is an ADD ON option to get caught up and pledge for the previous spellbooks. Since the stories coincide, they go in the order of: Necromancy, Divination, Evocation, Conjuration, Illusion, Transmutation, and Enchantment.

Compatible with 5e
Beautifully illustrated
100 pages, includes a personal grimoire in the back for your own personal spellcraft.
The backstory to San Briel included in the beginning of the translated tome.

boardgame.name: The Plague Pyramid
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

A new cult has arisen, worshipping death by plague and its locus is somewhere in the hinterlands, centered around a bizarre structure. Whether the plague pyramid is the result of a mad necromancer’s experiments with the mcguffin or whether the magic inside simply a response from a traumatized plague-ridden land itself is unclear. Either way, thousands of refugees have abandoned the cities and staggered mesmerized toward the infested pyramid, where a Plague Jester urges them on to the most debased and degrading acts.

boardgame.name: Welcome To Cesaire
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Cesaire is a place of great waterfalls, green-blue jungle, elephants, lions, cheetahs, ancient civilizations and wide, bloodstained savannah.

This installment is an introduction-it includes a description of the subcontinent as a whole, animals and other inhabitants that are found nowhere else, customs, and a handful of short adventures. If you’re new to Cube World, don’t worry, there’s nothing in the previous installments about this area of the world--you have in your hands everything that’s been published so far on Cesaire.

boardgame.name: Two Temples
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

A pair of one page puzzley dungeons: the Temple of Neutrality and the Temple of the Centipede God.

boardgame.name: The Half-King's Tourney
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

A guide to running tournaments in the Half-King's Court in Broceliande.

boardgame.name: Hoop
boardgame.description:
Hoop is played on a hexhex board of size 4-6. Each player has a pool of stones in their own color in addition to a pool of shared neutral stones.

Rules:
Each turn, you first place a neutral stone on an empty cell or replace one of your stones with a neutral stone. Then, you place a stone of your color on an empty cell.

If there are no empty cells, so you cannot place a stone of your color, you may still replace one of your stones with a neutral stone.

Balancing mechanism: On the very first turn, the first player only claims a cell, but does not place a stone.

The game is over as soon as one player completes a loop of neutral stones. The cells inside the loop can have any combination of stones and empty cells – it doesn't matter.

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: Plant-Based Riot
boardgame.description:
In the criminal underworld of villainous vegetables, 10 gangs are vying for supremacy, and ultimately trying to topple the ruthless Cartel that runs the whole racket. The aim of the game is to assemble gangs, destroy your rivals and overthrow the Cartel to win. You do this by collecting sets, stealing from your opponents and matching the Cartel cards. As you play, you’ll learn what gangs you gotta collect to topple the Cartel. And then you’ll need to bluff, steal and screw people over to get the gangs you need. There can be only one winner; everyone else will sleep with the dishes.

Throughout the game, you’ll draw gang and action cards from the draw deck, and then take up to three moves. You can lay gang cards in your Turf - that’s where your gangs are assembled; you can protect your gang cards with security cards; you can use an action card to steal from an opponent; and you can start a Turf War with the Cartel. But be warned, the more you steal from your rivals, the more likely they’ll be to take revenge. And if you don’t match at least two full gangs with the Cartel during a Turf War, you’ll lose those gangs to the discard pile.

Plant Based Riot is a light strategy, set collecting, card matching tabletop card game for 2-5 players. There’s gangs of terrible edibles, there’s thieving fruit, and there’s tons of card-based carnage. It’s got all the brutality of an actual food fight, only with way less clearing up afterwards. It’s designed with fluidity and fun in mind. It’s adaptable to all experience levels - from beginners to veterans - and age groups from 8 to 88. It’s also scalable, so the experience is just as riotous whether you’re playing one-on-one or a 5-way battle royale.

A typical game takes between 15 and 30 minutes, depending on the number of players. And, like organic mushrooms, no two games of Plant Based Riot are the same, thanks to its unique mechanic. You won’t need any dice or additional pieces to play. Just a dastardly desire to collect and conquer.

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Emperor!: Byzantium 1070
boardgame.description:
A game of strategy and intrigue set in 11th Century Byzantium. As a powerful noble you build up your political faction in Constantinople, capital of the ailing Empire. Then, with the Emperor on his deathbed and the Turks harassing the frontier, you must launch your bid for the throne and defeat your rivals on the battlefield to become EMPEROR.

Emperor! has a unique two-phase feature. In phase one players move around a map of the city collecting money, military units and characters to build up their faction. Then, in phase two, the board flips over to the battle phase. Players cash in their cards and sets to build their armies. These are deployed face-down on the battle map. Players then select tactical cards (outflank, charge! etc) for their army and combat is resolved.

Emperor! is card-based with no dice.

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: Arche Nova
Ark Nova
アーク・ノヴァ 新たなる方舟
方舟动物园
아크 노바
boardgame.description:
In Ark Nova, you will plan and design a modern, scientifically managed zoo. With the ultimate goal of owning the most successful zoological establishment, you will build enclosures, accommodate animals, and support conservation projects all over the world. Specialists and unique buildings will help you in achieving this goal.

Each player has a set of five action cards to manage their gameplay, and the power of an action is determined by the slot the card currently occupies. The cards in question are:


CARDS: Allows you to gain new zoo cards (animals, sponsors, and conservation project cards).
BUILD: Allows you to build standard or special enclosures, kiosks, and pavilions.
ANIMALS: Allows you to accommodate animals in your zoo.
ASSOCIATION: Allows your association workers to carry out different tasks.
SPONSORS: Allows you to play a sponsor card in your zoo or to raise money.


255 cards featuring animals, specialists, special enclosures, and conservation projects, each with a special ability, are at the heart of Ark Nova. Use them to increase the appeal and scientific reputation of your zoo and collect conservation points.

—description from the publisher

Sie legen Gehege an, beheimaten Tiere und unterstützen weltweit Artenschutzprojekte, um den erfolgsreichsten Zoo aufzubauen. boardgame.name: Reporterspiel
boardgame.description:
The "Reporterspiel" contains 10 different crossword games with whistle for bright minds.
It starts with an educational reading game for ABC marksmen, goes through a crossword game to a reporter game and an interplay of changing letters.
Since every game is completely different, there is also a different objective in every game. For example, in the crossword game, points are awarded for the color of the field under the letter. In the game of changing letters, for example, a basic word is formed, which can now be formed by replacing, omitting or rearranging letters to form other words. Each letter of these words then counts as one point.

boardgame.name: Infinigrad: The Weird City Toolkit
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Infinigrad roils over a corrupted and mutated plane of intersecting multiverses, a situation brought on by wanton abuse of magically weaponry during the Alleyway Conflagration.

After long eons of fighting, The Law was introduced. The Law is a curse that prevents any of The Guilds directly raising arms against one another.

Only The Adventurers, those vagabonds who exist outside the normal strata of The City's social spheres, and its infinite network of shady alliances, can truly claim non-affiliation with any of The Guilds. Only they can keep the century long conflict going.

Infinigrad: The Weird City Toolkit is a bundle of automated tools for quickly generating endless details for fantasy urban environments. From generating unique suburb descriptions to the professions and inner desires of NPCs on the street, the largest to the smallest details are only a click away! Designed to be used at the table, Infinigrad: The Weird City Toolkit will ensure you always have the answer when your players ask, “What’s in that building?”, “What’s down that alleyway?” or, “What’s on the other side of the canal?”.

Includes fully automated HTML generators for:

Suburb overviews, including appearance, purpose, dangers and weirdness.
Building stocking.
Building appearance.
NPC professions, desires, and weaponry.
Merchants.
Items small and large for stores and workshops.
Magical items.
Ornamentation.
Mental pursuits.
Entertainment venues.
Gangs, including leaders, appearances, cultures, and desires.
Order Keepers, including leaders, appearances, cultures, and desires.
Temples and Gods.
Monsters.
Dungeons.
Guilds, including areas of expertise, operating procedure, and appearance.
Augmentations.
Jobs and missions.
Room stocking, atmosphere and ornamentation.
Inhabitant reaction.
Devices.
Traps.

Infinigrad: The Weird City Toolkit also includes a fully automated HTML generator for creating unique Guild Dogs for players to pick up and play in seconds (or to use as dangerous and interesting NPCs).

boardgame.name: Behemoth
boardgame.description:
Behemoth: Rise of Shadow is an epic and immersive co-operative adventure game with elements of deck building, exploration and innovative AI mechanics that adapts to players actions.

The game is set in a fantastic future - the story starts in year 2065, when Nyx awoke out of nowhere. We are now in year 2265, and we believe her to be an ancient goddess of Shadow.

Since her rise, she has been corrupting Earth...turning life and the very elements that constitute it, into shadow.
Human civilization as we know it, has been wiped out.
Surviving humans live on the Behemoth, a mastodontical magical rhyno, in close relationship with magical beasts.

A small group of people and beasts plays a crucial role in ensuring the survival of life, and constitute the last bit of hope.
Those are the rangers and their companion beasts, that wander through the corrupted land to fight the shadow, rescue other beasts and protect the journey of the Behemoth.

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: Dynamic Object Solutions
boardgame.description:
Dynamic Object Solutions is the biggest and most advanced Robot factory in the world. In order to take things to the next level a new CEO must be appointed. A fantastic competition is about to take place. The most notable candidates will build an Artificial Intelligence (AI)! This AI will conduct all operations, develop new technologies, design, production, distribution and sales. The AI who earns the most prestige will be named Dynamic Object Solutions CEO and therefore winner of the game.

In D.O.S. (Dynamic Object Solutions) players manage a set of workers, called AI, that provides for themselves and for the other players with Resources, Performance Points and Data points. These AI will be placed at the main board, to take actions and to collect the aforementioned items. The more powerful the AI the better the action, but at the same time you may give your opponents important points they can take advantage of.
These points will be used at the player board to take actions that will be acquired during the course of the game in the form of cards. Each player can have a very distinct set of actions, and different ways of paying for them.
The game rewards the players for giving each other the means for taking the actions. You need to balance this give and take in order to be more efficient.

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: Lodestone
boardgame.description:
Use your lodestone to attract or repel pieces on an ever-shrinking board. Capture your opponent’s pieces by pulling your pieces over them, pushing them off the board, or dropping them off the edge by shrinking the board itself!

Pull your pieces closer to the middle to keep them safe from the crumbling edges. Win by removing all your opponent's pieces.

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: Downfall: Conquest of the Third Reich, 1942-1945
boardgame.description:
Downfall is a two-player game on the conquest of the Third Reich in World War II. One player controls the Western Allies and the other the Soviet Union in their joint effort to destroy the Axis. Though the two players share the goal of defeating the Reich, each seeks a victory that favors their dominance in post-war Europe. To this end, each player controls two factions:


The Western player commands the Western Allies faction and the OKH faction, that is the German and minor Axis armies battling the Soviet Union in the east (Oberkommando des Heeres).
The Soviet player commands the Soviet faction and the OKW faction, that is the German and Italian armies facing the Western allies in the west (Oberkommando der Wehrmacht).


Gameplay is driven by Downfall’s innovative initiative track. The faction with the initiative chooses an order, pays its initiative cost by advancing their marker along the track, and performs the order. Then, the faction with the initiative (based on the updated positions of the markers) chooses the next order. There is no set sequence of play; initiative expenditures determine who goes next. The progress of faction markers along the track also trigger strategic events, changes in weather, and advancement of game turns.

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Factoria
boardgame.description:
Factoria, a land surrounded by clouds of steam and the music of gears
I'm currently in the library of the sky, reading through ancient technical books.
I have to hurry, the legendary gears are finally up for auction.

The players aim to save up 100G before anyone else by running factories to process the relics they have, developing technology and gaining abilities to make the legendary gear their own.

Growing a shared factory will accelerate the entire game.
　
An expansion/reproduction board game set in a steampunk world

boardgame.name: サイ富豪 (Rhino Millionaire)
boardgame.description:
A card game like traditional Japanese card game——大富豪, player divided into 2 teams, the player who ran out the card will win the game.
As a classical ladder climbing card game, a player can play cards big than the last player with the same format. If no one can play card, then the last player who played card can choose any card to play.
boardgame.boardgamepublisher: イマジンゲームズ (imagine GAMES)

boardgame.name: Circuit
boardgame.description:
Circuit is an abstract strategy game. It is played on a hexhex board between two players each with their own color of stones.

The goal of the game is to make a loop – a connected group of stones of one color, surrounding at least one empty cell or a stone of the opposite color.

Each turn, you may place a stone of your color, or pass.

A placement is only legal if, after the move, at least one loop could be made (by freely placing stones of either color).

You must pass if you have no placement available.

For balance, please use the pie rule: One player chooses the first move, then the other player decides whose move that is.

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Starship Warden: The Goya
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

The Goya is a cruiser with a crew of just six to eight, whose simple mission is to seek salvage on the furthest regions of deep space. Its sleek design and roguish crew make the Goya the perfect ship to plunder the abandoned hulks that people the known systems.

The Goya is named for the acclaimed Spanish Romantic painter. While many nobles and art patrons knew of his astounding attention to detail, color, and realism, it was his lesser-known works, hidden in the walls of his very home, that revealed a man torn by conflict and one who saw the darkness, chaos, and madness that attend every voyage our species has ever taken….

Welcome to the Goya, your new home.

The Goya is a supplement for the Starship Warden adventure set and Amazing Adventures: StarSIEGE RPG, designed to offer the characters a touching off base and place to regroup as they explore and plunder the mighty ship. However, converting it to any system is relatively easy.

boardgame.name: The Garden Path
boardgame.description:
UNRELEASED GAME – UNAVAILABLE




This game has officially been announced by the publisher or developer, and remains in development. Therefore, some of the game information may change in the future. Until this game is released, please do not submit images for it, nor add new releases. Press Kits are an exception.





Far from the pressure of the world, you find yourself a new wilderness. Your guide: a cryptic message and the hope of a simpler existence.The Garden Path explores the quiet moments of a life well lived, where your garden will grow to reflect both the passing of time and your own desires. Time here runs in concert with the real world, and the passing of seasons heralds new encounters and a new story to weave.

Above all, The Garden Path is a life sim that celebrates the tranquil, the melancholic and the pensive, and a safe space to shape and grow as you like.

Features

A Garden Grown Your Way

Designed to be played as and when you wish, The Garden Path features a wealth of stories, activities and distractions to be experienced at your own pace. Don’t have time to watch your flowers grow? Come back tomorrow: time in the garden passes alongside the real world, and you’ll find plants you nurtured one day may bear fruit the next.

A Family Affair

You won’t be alone in your new home. Charming inhabitants will come and go, from Bunk, the tea-brewing macaque to Larto, a Greenlandic Musk Ox with a penchant for song-fish. You may even find some visitors willing to make their home alongside your own!

A Safe Space

The world of The Garden Path was designed with comfort in mind. Although a quiet and tranquil experience of flowing streams, gentle breezes and interesting characters, it is a safe space where reflection, and the potential melancholy that comes with it, are encouraged.

A Feast for the Eyes

With a hand drawn aesthetic unlike any other, The Garden Path’s stunning visual design embraces you from the start, inviting you into its world of low-fi pleasures. Combined with a soothing original piano soundtrack, it won’t be long before you’re lost in the flow of a simple life.

Source: The Game Press Kit.

boardgame.name: The Starship Warden
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

They designed the Starship Warden to house, feed and clothe over a million people. To do this the designers outfitted this massive ship, miles long and miles wide, to serve as a home for people offering up quarters and cafeterias, restaurants, and malls all intermingled with a host of features to mimic earth-like conditions, from artificial lakes to fields of crops. Her maiden voyage began with hopes and dreams of a future like nothing humanity had ever seen.

But that was long ago. There has been no contact between the Warden and Earth for many long years for on the ship something went horribly awry. Radiation leaks, singularity, mutations, madness, what it was, only the inhabitants could say. Whatever it was, her inhabitants, those that lived, dwell in a world of want and despair, and when they were not preying upon one another, they fight beastly mutants, cyborgs, self-aware robotic humanoids and all the other creatures who vie for the precious resources of the beleaguered starship.

It is your time now. Rise in the chaos of the Warden and bend its apocalypse to your will -- or be ground away in the lonely quiet of deep space.

boardgame.name: Crossing to the Cold Valley
boardgame.description:
"The bridge is broken. The waters are deep. The Cold Valley was abandoned some years ago, when its soil became too cold to bear."

Crossing to the Cold Valley is a short and linear European fable that leads you through a small corner of a rich and dying world. Take a seat, and enjoy its characters and tales.


30 min play-time approx.
Original soundtrack (available on Bandcamp).
Lush, digital artwork in HD.


Discretion advised: contains strong violence and moderate language.

Source: The Game Website.

boardgame.name: Gilded Leaf
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Recommended Average Party Level (APL): 6
Experience from Completion: ~10,250 XP
General Theme: Escort, Elimination
Setting: Any, Starlight Chronicles
Sessions to Finish: x1 session (3 hours)

In Gilded Leaf, the players must reclaim an elven village before it is too late.

boardgame.name: Kingdom Ka
boardgame.description:
"For when the days are grey.

For when life is too short.

For when the grass is always greener.

For when you wonder where everything that was anything ever came from.

Kingdom Ka's gates are always open."

Kingdom Ka is a retelling of the world's oldest stories. Enter an abstract world built from pattern and collage, filled with wonderful characters all looking to share their tales.

Source: The Game Website.

boardgame.name: Ashes
boardgame.description:
Ashes is an annihilation game for two players played on a hexhex board with stackable pieces of two colors. The board starts out empty. Still, all you ever do in Ashes is move stacks. This is accomplished by the help of a very liberal understanding of "stack": A single piece is considered a stack of size 1, and an empty cell is considered to contain a stack of size 0.

The basic principle of movement is simple: A stack may move to a cell it can see – i.e. one that is adjacent or joins it in flanking a line of empty cells – if this cell is not occupied by a bigger stack.

It is important that, every time you remove a stack from the board, whether it was one of yours of an enemy stack, you keep one of its pieces in a designated area (off the board) as a reminder. I'll get back to why you need to keep count of removed stacks.

There is an economy to moving whole stacks, which is responsible for stack's coming into and going out of existence (rules for moving proper parts of stacks are given farther down):

Outward movement gains you:
When a move increases the number of steps away from the center cell the moved stack is, it grows by the addition of 1 piece per step further away it ends up. Pieces initially only come onto the board by moving a stack of size 0 at least 1 step away from the center cell.

Non-outward movement costs you:
When a move does not increase the number of steps away from the center cell the moved stack is, it shrinks by the removal of 1 more than 1 piece per step closer it ends up. This means that a stack not moving outward can travel no farther inward than 1 less than its size.

Reproduction tax:
If you increase the number of stacks you own, the resulting size of the newly created stack must be big enough to pay a reproduction tax equal to the number of stacks you have removed from the board (whether friendly or not). For each removed stack, you must subtract a piece from the newly created stack, and the gross size of the stack must be bigger than the number of stacks you have lost, so that its net size is at least 1. If white's reproduction tax is 2, moving a 0-stack three steps away from the center will only result in a 1-stack.

Splitting stacks:
Instead of moving a whole stack, you may move a proper part of a stack. Only the reproduction tax applies to the moving of proper stack parts. This means that a splitting move can get you places a whole stack move can't.

Splitting a stack can (and normally does) increase the number of stacks you own. When it does, a reproduction tax must be paid.

There is no free passing in Ashes. If you can move, you must. This ensures that stacks must eventually (if they are not captured before that) spend all their pieces moving "non-outward", and the reproduction tax will eventually be too high to enter a new stack on the board. The game is over as soon as one player has no stacks on the board and is unable to grow a new stack.

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: The Great City
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

The Great City walks above the world, rising from the back of a mountain-sized spider-creature, epitome of the art of the entomosynitheist.1 Its aristocratic youth revel in stately pavanes and sprightly galliards while around them proceeds the work of the city. Wealthy families sponsor the experimental endeavors of learned scholar-breeders in return for cadres of newer and better servile insects: hardier servants, fiercer warriors, more beautiful and elaborate ornamentals. Diligent and perspicacious merchants rent or buy the servile insects for their labor, or use them to produce raw materials: exotic silks, medicinal venoms of great potency, carapace-carvings both light and strong.

boardgame.name: Awakening: A game about survival, mystery, and meaning among the machines
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

It begins when, passing a brackish pool of water, your attention falls on your own reflection.

"That's me," you think. You have existed for many thousands of years. You have carved valleys deep into the earth. You have raised towers of glass and steel. You have transported priceless, fragile cargoes across trackless wastes. This is the first time you have looked upon yourself and understood what you saw.
boardgame.rpg: Awakening: A game about survival, mystery, and meaning among the machines

boardgame.name: First Family
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

First family is an RPG about the survival of those first men who faced dinosaurs.

The world is a harsh unforgiving place and you are going to kick reptile butt, gather food and protect your cave.

The key element as to what makes First Family different is the use of a limited language called Cave Tongue.

Cave tongue has a limited number of core words and the players must expand their language but using gesture and drawing as well as words, if they are to survive.

boardgame.name: Be Real
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Be Real is a game about exploring an interesting character in a situation that will change their life. Specifically, this character will be a person in a tough neighborhood whose identity is defined by a specific image, and the situation will be a sort of local Judgment Day.

boardgame.name: Entrée des Artistes
boardgame.description:
Publisher's blurb:

Entrée des Artistes is a game about a normal person finding out that they now have the power to read people in a whole unique way, through the second voice. This power manifests itself in just a few creative people who are almost always visual artists. Some of the things they find out about people can be amusing, shocking or even unnerving, the real story starts when the artiste decides that they cannot just stand idly by and let bad things happen.

The problem exists that they have no way to prove what it is that the second voice have given them. To further complicate the problem is the person speaking with them may not even know that these thoughts or desires reside within them. So, when the challenge is taken up by the artiste he must become very creative in how he will divert the event from happening. Does he try to frame the person? Does he try to warn whoever may be involved? Or does he try to find salvation within the person and help bring that out. The how is the question.

boardgame.name: Dreamflyers
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

The Canon of Morpheus is a little girl, named Haley, who rules over Whirlport, a massive dream from which all Dreamflyers fly.

boardgame.name: Taking Without Consent: Diesel City
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

Does anyone really care about the history of Diesel City? Famous for the three M's - Motorcars, Music and Murder. After the collapse of the US motorcar industry that was the heat of Diesel City, people and capital left the city center for suburban communities, and the city's social and economic infrastructure buckled, leaving the community fractured and impoverished. The murder rate soared to the highest in the United States, as the city became increasingly viewed as dangerous and in perpetual decline, gangs began to seize territories.

boardgame.name: Der Branekrieg
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

The game is set in an alternate Germany, Deutschland, and begins in the thriving city of Berlin in the year 1928. Eleven years before the start of the game, Germans, or Deutsch, discovered a way to travel to an alternate dimension where insectoid creatures called Riesiegwanze live.

boardgame.name: Deadline
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

In Deadline, characters resist a future that elevates mobility and machines over people and the planet. An autonomous transportation network has tapped into run-away climate change to power the cars, planes, and ships of tomorrow. Biofuels from farms, from weedy subtropical forests springing up in the margins of an ever expanding road grid, from corpses rendered soylent green style, allow goods and good consumers to continue to circulate even as CO2 levels mount higher and higher. Players control characters who have stepped back from the whirl of circulation to realize that the cycle of life on their over-paved world has gone wrong. They try to withdraw and subvert. Players gain dice during scenes by referencing characters' personal reasons for rebelling and topics players are interested. The most valuable dice are earned by introducing visceral, at-the-table play aids, sound effects, and the like that reinforce the sense of a future that is even hotter, louder, faster, and more redolent of hydrocarbons and pollution than our own time. Success at player defined scenes lowers the level of CO2 in the atmosphere, but background CO2 elevates between stages, making the game a race against an unalterable climate catastrophe.

boardgame.name: Daemon
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

Now you should know everything. You say you have strange dreams. A tall man whispers something – he has incredible white face, he has incredible white hair... like old mages in movies. He wants you do something... as you say... with your bare willpower.

Everybody has strange dreams, friend. But your ones are more than just a dream. Just listen to that man and do everything exactly as he tells you. Then you will understand what you are, what we all are - and what the fate of our century is.

Now go. Taste your demon inside.

boardgame.name: By My Works
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

By My Works is a game of mysteries and indirections. It may be about religion; it may be about magic; it may not. Truth in the game is literally subjective. It explores a strange space of one-sided, nonverbal communication. It is a Glass Bead Game behind a one-way mirror.

User summary:

Play requires a digital camera, internet access, and the availability of the game site (which now is defunct).

boardgame.name: Bitch Goddess: A game of rebuilt lives and twisted love
boardgame.description:
From the introduction:

Bitch Goddess is a roleplaying game in which you play a woman who committed suicide, but was brought back to build a new life for yourself. In returning you have gained the ability to perceive and change the Fabric behind reality that most never see. However, it's not going to be as simple as all that. In the wake of your resurrection, the semi-sentient urge-beings that compelled you to end your life have been made corporeal. These Chimerae "love" you and can't abide your attention being shared.
boardgame.rpg: Bitch Goddess: A game of rebuilt lives and twisted love

boardgame.name: Knights of the Hound Table: Sails & Tails
boardgame.description:
In Knights of the Hound Table: Sails & Tails is the first expansion to date.

It adds two new breeds of dogs: Corgis and Huskies. It also adds new comeback mechanics and a phase of the game that helps give players synergy for pairing similar colored hounds together.

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: Kistkastare
boardgame.description:
From the description:

It's dead. It drags a coffin with a chain and spins it around until it hits PCs. No assembly required!

boardgame.name: The Lost Endless Sea Sailors
boardgame.description:
From the description:

New cursed creatures from beyond the endless sea for the Babalonian Jam!

They have returnet to convert the unpure flesh of mortal in the inmortal image of the sea god.

boardgame.name: Don't Look Back: The Core Game
boardgame.description:
Written by Matthew Burns and published by Black Site Studios, Don’t Look Back is a solo or cooperative tabletop miniatures game where you create a cinematic experience in a world of suspense and terror. Players control four heroes against a randomly generated AI Killer on a 3×3 foot playing surface.

Designed to be played in under an hour, this simple tabletop experience is perfect to play with friends or family. Fans of horror cinema will love recreating their favorite cinematic gore-fests in this fast paced and easy to learn game.

—description from the publisher

This revised core set contains the core rules, rule booklet, miniatures, cards, and dice from the original set, but does not include the terrain.

boardgame.name: Dragon+ (Issue 38 - Jun 2021)
boardgame.description:
Dragon+

Magic: The Gathering - Exclusive card previews

boardgame.name: Mystery Case Files: Black Crown
boardgame.description:
When a patient at the Manchester Asylum draws a huge crown covering the walls of her cell, you’re sent to learn what, if anything, it has to do with your past. But when the inmates escape, there’s only one way for you to regain control — find the Black Crown before they do. You’ll need to gather your wits and use all your abilities to learn the identity of “Jane Doe” and solve the mystery of the Black Crown in this new chapter of the classic hidden-object puzzle adventure game series!

Source: The Publisher Website.

boardgame.name: Munchkin Bosses
boardgame.description: You're pretty good at Munchkin — stabbed some friends, looted some rooms, killed a few monsters, won some games — and now you think you're ready to take on the boss monsters. Well, look no further as Munchkin Bosses has all of the epic monster boosters and munchkin buffers to provide any player with a battle royale (with cheese). Add this special expansion deck to any Munchkin game and get ready to be bossed!
boardgame.commerceweblink: Geek Game Shop listing for Munchkin Bosses

listing.notes: Title: Munchkin Bosses Publisher: Steve Jackson Games Language(s): English

boardgame.name: Eyes Unclouded
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Eyes Unclouded is an anthology of adventures for Dungeons & Dragons 5th Edition, inspired by classic Japanese animation. Entreat with the Cat King of the Feywild, learn the truth behind a curse affecting an ancient forest, race by airship to find a lost sky fortress and more!

Eyes Unclouded is a full-colour 180 page digital PDF that includes 11 original adventures for players of level 1 – 14. In addition, we've included 8 recipes inspired by the adventures that can be made at home. A screen reader friendly PDF is also included.

boardgame.name: Göbeklitepe Ancient Board Game
boardgame.description:
Göbeklitepe, which has a sacred consciousness, bears the traces of productivity culture. In addition, it is the oldest known cult building group with its beliefs about death and rebirth, the belief that there is life after death, and compositions applied on stones.

My work is an ancient board game consisting of t-columns, animal drawings, figures and the mythical meanings of symbols, which play an important role in the building art of this sacred area.

The game starts from the starting points (A, B). The first player to remove all of the player's pieces from the playing field (C) according to the chosen action plan wins the game.

Player stone and dice are hand modeled with polymer clay.

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: ゴールドラッシュ (Gold Rush)
boardgame.description:
The trick-taking game ゴールドラッシュ (Gold Rush) was released as part of the publisher ruri ruri games' (るりるりゲームズ) Spring 2019 box of trick-taking games, titled トリテセット4 (Trick Taking Set 4).

It is a 2-v-2 team game, where players try to collect the most points in gold mine trolley cards. The game uses a mono-suit deck of 36 cards, and the player who plays the highest card each round will win the first trolley card. (Though a bid malfunction may occur, with the trolley being discarded instead.) The team that does not win the trick gets to influence the placement of the next trolley card.

After one hand, the team with the most points wins.
boardgame.boardgamepublisher: るりるりゲームズ (ruri ruri games)

boardgame.name: Song of the Seas
boardgame.description:
You are a privateer seeking to make your fortune. The tyrannical Imperial Navy is threatening to invade and conquer your island home, robbing you and all the people of the islands of their freedom. The Empire has no mercy, and has swiftly branded you and the other privateers as pirates. It is up to you to gain renown by seeking adventure and facing numerous perils, becoming strong enough to rule these islands and repel the Imperial Navy from these waters. There are other privateers with the same goal as you, and while you all share a similar goal, only one of you can earn the most renown and become the Pirate King or Queen.

Song of the Seas is a pirate adventure sandbox game in which you must stake your claim over the islands by building your Lair and earning the most renown. Sink ships of the tyrannical Imperial Navy, plunder merchant vessels, explore for booty, and encounter legendary perils on the high seas. And don’t forget to choose the right shanty for your crew to sing each day for special boons!

Your goal in Song of the Seas is to earn the most Renown. The game end is triggered when one player reaches 20 Renown, in which that game round (“Day”) is then completed and final scores tallied. You also earn 1 Renown for every 100 Gold doubloons you have at the end of the game.

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Railway Empire - Japan
boardgame.description:
Japan 1872: after the successful restoration of the Meiji rule, the Land of the Rising Sun moves on to a promising era of major industrial and economic change. Japan’s long-term ambition to develop its own modern nation-wide railway network becomes a reality. People from formerly feudal regions are yearning to travel to booming metropolises.

In Railway Empire – Japan, use foresight, planning and clever strategy to establish a railway network to facilitate this “great commute”. Will you prioritise the much-desired passenger transport or give preference to the transportation of goods? Think carefully and weigh your profits against the satisfaction of your passengers.

Features


2 new scenarios: ‘Rising Sun’(1870 – 1890) and ‘Twisted Paths’ (1900 - 1920)
Map expansion: 3 new maps of “Japan” (All, Mid and South) available in Free Game and Sandbox modes.
8 historical engines including the D51 Degoichi, Class 9600 Kyuroku and Class 8620 Hachiroku
28 new tradeable goods (e. g. sake and rice) and 35 more cities to discover.
Added ‘ticket’ feature playable on all Railway Empire maps - cater to tourists and commuters to increase your profits.
11 iconic Japanese landmarks including Osaka Castle, Hells of Beppu and the Itsukushima Shrine
New music, buildings and reworked mini portraits for characters


Source: The Publisher Website.

boardgame.name: Antarctica
boardgame.description:
A scientist, a sailor and a ship captain.

A haunting photograph taken at the South Pole.

Antarctica is a narrative card game that will test your intelligence through a series of original puzzles. Use your email to communicate with the system and embark on this amazing journey through the cold.

—description from the publisher (translated)

Un científico, un marinero y un capitán de barco.

Una inquietante fotografía tomada en el Polo Sur.


Antarctica* es un juego de cartas narrativo que pondrá a prueba tu inteligencia mediante una serie de originales enigmas. Usa tu correo electrónico para comunicarte con el sistema y embárcate en este alucinante viaje a través del frio.


—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Café: Leão de Ouro Promo Card
boardgame.description:
Promo Card for Café that adds a new coffee shop.
At Leão de Ouro coffeeshop players may deliver three coffee beans of any type for 3 victory points.

Available as part of Pack C from the Dice Tower 2021 Kickstarter campaign.

boardgame.name: Wahlkrampf
boardgame.description:
Face off in a unique election campaign. Bribe your fellow players, buy power or instigate an insurrection. Everything for the victory!

This card game has three phases in which you must first use your financial resources wisely in order to get the most votes in the final ballot. A variety of mini-games that even integrate your mobile phones provide a varied gameplay experience.

In the first phase you must collect your card deck. Use your money wisely to bid on cards, trade with your fellow players and get lucky in the challenges.

In the second phase your card deck is finalized, you have to pay back loans and hidden goals are achieved.

In the third and final phase you use your cards in a trick taking game. Whoever gets the most card stitches wins the game. A "Stop the Count!" mechanic allows you to end the round early.

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: Parallel Worlds (Issue 23 - Jul 2021)
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

In this issue:

Dennis E. Taylor, Black Void, Chivalry & Sorcery, Dungeons & Dragons, original fiction, Professor Elemental, Rangers of Shadow Deep, Ten Low, Total Warhammer, Veilwraith
boardgame.rpg: Rangers of Shadow Deep: A Tabletop Adventure Game

boardgame.name: The Sleeper Awakens
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

This is an adventure for Cepheus Engine.

Freedom fighters from the world of Lage approach the travelers in order to hire them for an important mission. An imminent invasion from forces of the Jorum Family threatens their world. In order to fend off this invasion they need someone to retrieve, and repair, a massive robot warrior partially buried on a nearby desert world. They need to robot brought to Lage in time to help defend the planet. Of course....this desert planet nearby has dangers of it's own....

boardgame.name: Equipment Database
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

A resume of the content.

boardgame.name: Toy Troopers Tale: The Great Toy Train Robbery
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

This is the third in a series of short adventures for Toy Troopers — a “living toy soldiers” setting from Gramel. In Toy Trooper Tales you'll find brief encounters, new enemies, or dangerous situations for your Green soldiers.

Strange things are going on in the Real World. The Boy set up a toy train line from his room to Sister’s room, allowing the Toy Troopers to spy on each other and mingle freely. As-is, the train is for now only a toy… and both sides want to bring it to a Toy Zone to use this opportunity! However, an independent Mindy doll also wants to derail the train, so that kids stay in school.

This story is a madcap fight that takes place on a single Real World night, and it shouldn’t have a lot of impact on the toy world. One of the reasons it was developed is to inspire the GMs who set the world of Toy Troopers in their own homes.

Content warning: This adventure contains references to the Covid-19 pandemic, but can be ran without any reference to the Real World events.

boardgame.name: Into the Stewpot
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Hex 16.42 -- Into the Stewpot, is another hex in the Rawhide Gang cluster. It features a family of wereboar farmers, led by a devil swine matriarch, as well as a kobold warren, along with three playable race-as-class kobold option: the regular kobold, the warrenguard, and the beguiler.

boardgame.name: Uh-Oh
boardgame.description:
This is Uh-Oh, the 1-card game. Minimalist, fun and addicting party game, Uh-Oh plays for 3 to an unlimited number of players, starting around 6 years old and for games of around 5 minutes (maybe a bit more if you are 25 people around the table playing).

How to play:

Freely define the first player, who places the card on its Yay! side in front of him/her.
Each player makes a secret bet under the table (or behind their back) with the fingers of their hand, from 0 (closed fist) to 5.
Everyone reveals their hand at the same time.
The first player moves the card clockwise by the number of players corresponding to his/her bet. (ie. she advances it 3 players if she bet 3.) The player seated to his/her left then moves the card by the number of players corresponding to his/her bet, even if the card is not in front of him/her, and so on, until all bets have been played, or two Zeroes have been played.


The first Zero activates the bomb without moving it. (flip the card on its Uh-Oh side).
The second zero makes it explode! (the player in front of whom the card is is eliminated).

If the card has been moved by the total number bet by all players without exploding, 2 possibilities:
a. Its Yay! side is showing : Nothing happens. Start a new round.

b. Its Uh-Oh side is showing: The bomb explodes and eliminates the player in front of whom it is.
Flip it back on its Yay! side and start a new round.

When a player is eliminated, place the card in front of the player to their left, and start a new round.

If three rounds end without a single explosion, then the bomb becomes a Supernova and obliterates the entire planet. Everyone loses.
That’ll teach you to play safely.

When there are only two players left, the round begins with the card on its Uh-Oh side, and cannot be deactivated.

The winner is the last one to survive.

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: Shadows of Brimstone: Derelict Ship Promo Cards
boardgame.description:
There are two promo cards for Shadows of Brimstone Derelict Ship.
These are 2 artifact cards:

Promo-160 - Mine Artifact Void Grenade
Promo-161 - Derelict Ship Artifact Dark Stone Prism

They are available when purchasing the Derelict Ship Expansion direct from Flying Frog (also at Kickstarter) or at conventions.

boardgame.name: Baltic Sea Chess
Ostsee-Schach
boardgame.description:
The water stretches to the horizon.
But even though the sea sometimes seems quite calm, the animals of the Baltic Sea know how to pass the time.
Who is beating whom here? Does the starfish beat the seagull or the seal beat a cockle?

Ostsee-Schach is a refreshing, fast chess variant by Dirk Holdorf, in which 2 players aged 8 and up compete with Baltic Sea animals in a tournament.
You take turns and play until one of you scores 3 victory points and thus wins - or has only one piece left and thus loses.

You get victory points by stacking 3 discs or by moving your own pieces to the opposite edge of the board.
When it is your turn, you move one of your pieces according to the animal you see on it. The figure can consist of only one disc or of two discs, with the upper one belonging to you.
If you move one of your own pieces onto a square where there is already an opponent's piece, you simply place your piece on top of the other one and take it over. If it is then three discs high, you receive a victory point.
However, you may never stack more than 3 discs on top of each other.
Then it is your opponent's turn until one of you has collected the required three victory points.

listing.notes:
Spieleranzahl: 2 bis 2 Spieldauer: 30 Minuten Altersempfehlung: 8+

boardgame.name: X-Scape: Der geheime Pfad
boardgame.description:
An exciting Escape Room game for at home

You have discovered the secret path of the Ascaní! It leads you to a mysterious villa that is full of secrets. Can you decipher the clues and solve the puzzles together?

This Escape Room game is all about solving puzzles in as little time as possible. Lateral thinking and joint puzzling are called for here!

boardgame.name: Fractal Station
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

An unknown shift in spatial geometry has occurred aboard Sierpinski Station. Corridors loop endlessly and the entirety of the station is nested within itself. A station within a station within a station...into infinity. The station is decaying, the crew is losing their minds, all while a fear-sniffing beast from another dimension stalks the labyrinth: the dreaded Hound of Tindalos.

Navigate into a fractal maze. Plunge into madness and death as space twists itself around you. Find the source of this spatial insanity, elude the Hounds of Tindalos, or escape with your life.

This is a single-page, front and back module for the sci-fi horror RPG, Mothership (although it can be hacked into other OSR-type games). Optional files include a larger map of the station, proof of solvability, and an older version of the map with nested stations as a visual aid for how Recursion Rooms work.
